lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and correctly use adjectives with and without nouns (e.g., “It’s long.” / “It’s a long ruler.”).
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board write: “It’s long.” and “It’s a long rope.” Ask students to match sentence types with images from the SB.
stretchStrategies: Adjective Switch-Up – Write 3–5 sentence frames on the board with missing adjectives (“It’s a ___ teddy.” “It’s ___.”). Students must race to complete each with a different adjective than their partner, using correct structure. Encourage them not to repeat any adjective they’ve already used.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the initial sounds (b, f, u, j).
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say /b/, /f/, /u/, /j/. Students repeat and circle those letters in words in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Adjective Switch-Up – Write 3–5 sentence frames on the board with missing adjectives (“It’s a ___ teddy.” “It’s ___.”). Students must race to complete each with a different adjective than their partner, using correct structure. Encourage them not to repeat any adjective they’ve already used.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete short sentence frames (e.g., “It’s ___.” and “It’s a ___ teddy bear.”) using the correct adjectives.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Display sentence frames: “It’s ___.” and “It’s a ___ teddy bear.” Students complete with their own adjectives and items.
stretchStrategies: Adjective Switch-Up – Write 3–5 sentence frames on the board with missing adjectives (“It’s a ___ teddy.” “It’s ___.”). Students must race to complete each with a different adjective than their partner, using correct structure. Encourage them not to repeat any adjective they’ve already used.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
